title: The Resurrection and Ascension
shortSummary: Luke 24 recounts the resurrection of Jesus Christ, His appearances to His followers, and His ascension into heaven. This chapter affirms the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy, the reality of Christ’s bodily resurrection, and the commissioning of the disciples to proclaim repentance and forgiveness of sins to all nations.
timeline: c. AD 30-33 - The Resurrection and Ascension of Jesus Christ

keyCharacters.name: Mary Magdalene
keyCharacters.description: A devoted follower of Jesus who was among the first to discover the empty tomb and report the resurrection.

keyCharacters.name: Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus’ closest disciples who investigates the empty tomb and later witnesses the risen Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Cleopas
keyCharacters.description: One of the two disciples traveling to Emmaus who encounters the risen Jesus and has his understanding of Scripture opened.

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The risen Lord who appears to His followers, explains Scripture concerning Himself, and ascends to heaven.

definitions.definition: A tomb or burial place, specifically referring to where Jesus was laid after His crucifixion.
A Messianic title Jesus frequently used for Himself, emphasizing both His humanity and divine mission.
The forgiveness or pardoning of sins, granted through repentance and faith in Christ.
Refers to the Holy Spirit, whom Jesus promised to send to empower His disciples after His ascension.

outline.heading: The Empty Tomb and Angelic Message
outline.description: Women discover Jesus’ tomb empty and are told by angels that He has risen, fulfilling His predictions. Peter confirms the empty tomb, though initial disbelief remains among the disciples.

outline.heading: The Road to Emmaus
outline.description: Two disciples encounter the risen Jesus on the road but do not recognize Him until He breaks bread with them. Jesus explains how the Scriptures foretold His suffering and resurrection, strengthening their faith.

outline.heading: Jesus Appears to the Disciples
outline.description: Jesus appears to the gathered disciples, showing His hands and feet to prove His bodily resurrection and eats with them, dispelling their doubts and fears.

outline.heading: The Great Commission and Ascension
outline.description: Jesus opens the disciples’ understanding of Scripture, commissions them to preach repentance and forgiveness, promises the Holy Spirit, blesses them, and ascends into heaven, marking the beginning of their mission.

application: Trust in the truth of Christ’s resurrection as the foundation of your faith and hope.
Seek to understand and apply Scripture, recognizing Jesus as the fulfillment of God’s promises.
Be bold witnesses of the gospel, sharing the message of repentance and forgiveness with others.
Depend on the Holy Spirit’s power for guidance, strength, and effective ministry.

keyVerses.text: He is not here, but is risen: remember how he spake unto you when he was yet in Galilee,
keyVerses.significance: This verse proclaims the central truth of Christianity—the resurrection of Jesus, confirming His victory over death.

keyVerses.text: And beginning at Moses and all the prophets, he expounded unto them in all the scriptures the things concerning himself.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus reveals that the Old Testament Scriptures point to Him, emphasizing the unity and divine inspiration of the Bible.

keyVerses.text: And said unto them, Thus it is written, and thus it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead the third day: And that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in his name among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: These verses outline the necessity of Christ’s suffering and resurrection and the global mission entrusted to His followers.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass, while he blessed them, he was parted from them, and carried up into heaven.
keyVerses.significance: The ascension marks Jesus’ exaltation and the completion of His earthly ministry, preparing the way for the coming Holy Spirit.
